awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Dean Wilcox from Dartmouth College as he seeks to obtain new insights into the binding of metal ions to proteins. Metals are often used in Nature due to the unique reactivity they provide when they are bound to a protein (e.g., metalloenzymes).  Proteins play key roles in the uptake, transport, use and excretion of biologically essential metals (e.g., zinc, copper, iron), as well as toxic ones (e.g., mercury, lead, cadmium), by living organisms. Dr. Wilcox's studies are providing fundamental insights into how proteins interact with metal ions in the cell. Additionally, students working on this project are gaining important knowledge and valuable skills for their careers in science and education, thereby enhancing the scientific workforce.

This research quantifies the thermodynamics of metal ions binding to proteins in order to provide a better understanding of metal contributions to protein stability and protein modulation of metal redox properties. Fundamental new insights about metal-protein interactions are being obtained from studies that correlate metal-binding thermodynamics to the thermodynamics of metal stabilization of the resulting metalloprotein.  The Wilcox group quantifies solvent contributions to metal-binding thermodynamics, and determine metal contributions (bonding, electrostatics) to metalloproteins binding to DNA. A method that determines the metalloprotein reduction thermodynamics from calorimetric measurements of metal binding is being applied to selected metalloproteins and enzymes.  These methods provide insight into protein modulation of the metal reduction potential, as well as proton transfer accompanying reduction. Several variants of azurin with higher and lower reduction potentials, polysaccharide monooxygenase, which has a unique Cu(I) coordination, and tyramine-monooxygenase, which has two mechanistically-distinct copper ions are being studied. Finally, this method is being extended to studies of the copper enzyme superoxide dismutase to quantify the thermodynamics and accompanying proton transfer reactions.

por.por_cntn:
All living organisms require trace metals, including zinc and copper, for catalytic roles in enzymes or, much like a safety pin, structural roles in proteins. Therefore, pathways for the import, transport, delivery and excretion of essential metals, as well as mechanisms to eliminate toxic metals, are crucial for life. Since metals are generally bound to proteins for their biological role and both the managing of essential metals and removal of toxic metals requires specific proteins, the binding of metal ions to proteins is central to many biological processes. The aim of this project was to quantify the thermodynamics of metal binding to determine the molecular basis for the affinity and selectivity of certain proteins for their essential metal, as well as competing (toxic) metals. This project primarily used the technique of calorimetry, which measures the release or absorption of heat, to quantify the binding of metal ions to proteins and thereby understand key steps in biological pathways. These metal-binding measurements had two important goals.

 

The first goal was to provide fundamental new insight about metal-protein interactions, either contributions of the metal to protein stability or tuning of the metal properties when it is bound to a protein. For the former, zinc is required to stabilize many proteins that bind to DNA and two classes of these zinc-stabilized DNA-binding proteins have been investigated. We found that one class, the so-called WRKY domain of plant proteins, has an exceptionally high affinity for zinc and we determined its molecular origin, which ensures that the protein retains its DNA-binding ability under stressful conditions when zinc is scarce. For the other class, which includes two proteins that bind zinc with four cysteine amino acids (the so-called GATA and GR-DBD domains), we discovered a unique electrostatic protein-stabilizing feature that is directly coupled with zinc binding. To better understand protein tuning of metal properties, we have developed a new protocol that uses calorimetric measurements to determine how the metal-protein bonding and protein environment affect the ability of the metal to accept or donate an electron (reduction or oxidation) in biological pathways.

 

The second goal was to understand metal binding that is the basis for biological function. This involved quantifying a) mercury and other metals binding to proteins in the Mer pathway that protects microorganisms from toxic metals, which involved the challenge of measuring the very high metal affinities of these proteins, b) copper and zinc binding to the protein metallothionein-3, which is involved in the homeostasis of these metals in neural tissue and is implicated in certain neurological disorders, c) zinc binding to insulin, which reversibly stabilizes a hexameric structure in the insulin storage vesicles of pancreatic cells, and d) inhibitors binding to the copper of the enzyme copper/zinc superoxide dismutase, which provides insight about the binding of the substrate superoxide.

 

This project had three areas of broader impact. First is the quantitative molecular insight it has provided about the structural roles of metals when they are bound to proteins and the mechanistically important binding of metal ions to proteins, including cases that are related to conditions of dysfunction, toxicity and disease. Second is the protocols and data analysis for calorimetric measurements involving metals that we have developed and share/disseminate. Third is the education and training of students working on this project and the benefits that these provide for their future careers in science and technology.
